introduction.p: So far, we have focused our attention on a small collection of basic functions functions \frac{1}{1-x}, \ln(1+x), \sin(x), \cos(x), and e^x and their Taylor series centered at a = 0. One of the reasons we were able to find these Taylor series is the clear patterns in the derivatives of each of these functions. While we can always use Definition to find the first few terms of a Taylor series, finding a pattern among the various derivatives is challenging for most functions. In Preview Activity, we explore this issue and investigate a different approach to finding the Taylor series of the function.

subsection.title: Using substitution and algebra to find new Taylor series expressions
subsection.p: The substitution technique we used in Preview Activity can be used to find the Taylor series for any function whose structure is similar to that of a Taylor series we already know.

example.statement: Find the Taylor series expansion for g(x) = x^4 \cdot \cos(x^3) and determine the x-values for which the series converges.

solution.p:
Because \cos(x^3) is part of the function whose Taylor series we seek, we start with the familiar series for \cos(x). We know that
f(u) = \cos(u) = 1 - \frac{1}{2!}u^2 + \frac{1}{4!}u^4 - \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{(2n)!} u^{2n} + \cdots
for all real numbers u.

By letting u = x^3 in Equation, it follows that
\cos(x^3) = 1 - \frac{1}{2!}(x^3)^2 + \frac{1}{4!}(x^3)^4 - \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{(2n)!} (x^3)^{2n} + \cdots , or
\cos(x^3) = 1 - \frac{1}{2!}x^6 + \frac{1}{4!}x^{12} - \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{(2n)!} x^{6n} + \cdots . Then, multiplying both sides of Equation by x^4, we find that
g(x) = x^4 \cos(x^3) = x^4 - \frac{1}{2!}x^{10} + \frac{1}{4!}x^{16} - \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{(2n)!} x^{6n+4} + \cdots . Since Equation is valid for every real number u, letting u = x^3 tells us that Equation is valid for every real number x. The Ratio Test can be used to show that multiplying every term of a Taylor series by the same power of x does not change the set of x-values for which the series converges, so the Taylor series for g(x) also converges for every value of x.

subsection.title: Differentiating and integrating Taylor series
subsection.p:
In Section, we discussed the challenge posed by the definite integral
\int_0^1 e^{-x^2} \, dx . Because we are unable to find a simple algebraic antiderivative for the function e^{-x^2}, we cannot use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus to evaluate the integral exactly. One approach is to estimate the integral using an effective numerical approximation technique such as Simpson's Rule.

Our recent work with Taylor series now suggests another way to evaluate \int_0^1 e^{-x^2} \, dx, and this approach also provides new options for finding additional Taylor series. In Activity, we found that
e^{-x^2} = 1 - x^2 + \frac{1}{2!}x^4 - \frac{1}{3!}x^6 + \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{n!} x^{2n} + \cdots
and that this representation of e^{-x^2} is valid for every value of x. This infinite series representation naturally suggests that we could find an antiderivative of e^{-x^2} by integrating both sides of Equation. Doing so, we see
\int e^{-x^2} \, dx =\mathstrut \amp \int \left( 1 - x^2 + \frac{1}{2!}x^4 - \frac{1}{3!}x^6 + \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{n!} x^{2n} + \cdots \right) \, dx =\mathstrut \amp C + x - \frac{1}{3}x^3 + \frac{1}{5 \cdot 2!} x^5 - \frac{1}{7 \cdot 3!}x^7 + \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{(2n+1) \cdot n!} x^{2n+1} + \cdots

We might wonder how integrating a Taylor series changes the values of x for which the series converges. It turns out that integrating a power series has almost no effectIt is possible for the convergence status at the endpoints of the interval to change, but we are normally not concerned with those specific x-values. on where the series converges (nor does differentiating such a series), as stated in a result from advanced calculus, The Power Series Differentiation and Integration Theorem.

assemblage.title: The Power Series Differentiation and Integration Theorem

subsection.p: The Power Series Differentiation and Integration Theorem tells us that when it comes to taking a derivative or antiderivative, we can treat infinite Taylor series almost as if they were finite polynomials: we can differentiate or integrate a Taylor series term-wise following the Power Rule for differentiating or integrating x^n. This fact enables us to find many more Taylor series of interesting functions.

subsection.title: Alternating series
subsection.p:
Recall that if \lim_{k \to \infty} a_k \neq 0, then the series \sum a_k diverges by the Divergence Test. From this point forward, we will thus only consider alternating series
\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} (-1)^{k+1} a_k
in which the sequence a_k consists of positive numbers that decrease to 0. The nth partial sum S_n is
S_n = \sum_{k=1}^n (-1)^{k+1} a_k .

Notice that
S_2 = a_1 - a_2, and since a_1 \gt a_2 we have 0 \lt S_2 \lt S_1 .
S_3 = S_2+a_3 and so S_2 \lt S_3. But a_3 \lt a_2, so S_3 \lt S_1. Thus, 0 \lt S_2 \lt S_3 \lt S_1 .
S_4 = S_3-a_4 and so S_4 \lt S_3. But a_4 \lt a_3, so S_2 \lt S_4. Thus, 0 \lt S_2 \lt S_4 \lt S_3 \lt S_1 .
S_5 = S_4+a_5 and so S_4 \lt S_5. But a_5 \lt a_4, so S_5 \lt S_3. Thus, 0 \lt S_2 \lt S_4 \lt S_5 \lt S_3 \lt S_1 .

subsection.p:
Note further that the absolute value of the difference between the (n-1)st partial sum S_{n-1} and the nth partial sum S_n is
\left\lvert S_n - S_{n-1} \right\rvert = a_n .

Because the sequence \{a_n\} converges to 0, the distance between successive partial sums becomes as close to zero as we'd like, and thus the sequence of partial sums converges (even though we don't know the exact value to which it converges).
The preceding discussion has demonstrated the truth of the Alternating Series Test. alternating series test

assemblage.title: The Alternating Series Test
assemblage.p:
Given an alternating series
\sum (-1)^k a_k , if the sequence \{a_k\} of positive terms decreases to 0 as k \to \infty, then the alternating series converges.

subsection.p: Note that if the limit of the sequence \{a_k\} is not 0, then the alternating series diverges.

If the series converges, the argument for the Alternating Series Test also provides us with a method to determine how close the nth partial sum S_n is to the actual sum of the series. To see how this works, let S be the sum of a convergent alternating series, so
S = \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} (-1)^k a_k .

Therefore, the value of the term a_{n+1} provides an error estimate for how well the partial sum S_n approximates the actual sum S. We summarize this fact in the statement of the Alternating Series Estimation Theorem. alternating series estimation theorem

assemblage.title: Alternating Series Estimation Theorem
assemblage.p:
If the alternating series
\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} (-1)^{k+1}a_k
has positive terms a_k that decrease to zero as k \to \infty, and
S_n = \sum_{k=1}^{n} (-1)^{k+1}a_k
is the nth partial sum of the alternating series, then
\left\lvert \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} (-1)^{k+1}a_k - S_n \right\rvert \leq a_{n+1} .

solution.p:
If we let S be the sum of the series \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{k+1}}{k}, then we know that
\left| S_{100} - S \right| \lt a_{101} .

Now
a_{101} = \frac{1}{101} \approx 0.0099 , so the 100th partial sum is within 0.0099 of the sum of the series. We have discussed the fact (and will later verify) that
S = \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{k+1}}{k} = \ln(2) , and so S \approx 0.693147 while
S_{100} = \sum_{k=1}^{100} \frac{(-1)^{k+1}}{k} \approx 0.6881721793 .
We see that the actual difference between S and S_{100} is approximately 0.0049750013, which is indeed less than 0.0099.
